Image Gallery

Day One, Year Zero

Cambodia was a recently decolonized state previously governed by France until 1953, when Prince Norodom Sihanouk declared independence. A military coup deposed Sihanouk and handed power to Marshal Lon Nol who was backed by pro-American associates. Officially, Sihanouk maintained a position of neutrality in the war between Vietnam and the United States, even though some supplies were given to the Vietnamese communists and the U.S. was allowed to bomb Viet Cong hideouts in Cambodia illegitimately.

Therefore, the U.S. supported the military coup by Marshall Lon Nol to acquire access to Cambodia during the war. In the beginning, Pol Pot and the Khmer Rouge allied themselves with Marshall Lon Nol for the coup, but when power was in the hands of Lon Nol, they defected and civil war broke out. Lon Nol was fighting communists in Vietnam as external threats and the Khmer Rouge internally within Cambodian borders with limited resources. On April 17, 1975, the Khmer Rouge seized control of the country’s capital city, Phnom Penh, effectively ousting the Lon Nol government.

When the Khmer Rouge marched into the capital, Phnom Penh, thousands of terrified people fled - some towards the border with Thailand, others flooded the gates of the French Embassy. The Cambodian genocide began thereafter.

Survivors sift through rubble after the Khmer Rouge bombed Phnom Penh, the capital city, on January 1, 1975. Four months later, the party took the city, on April 17, 1975, and began their mission of returning Cambodia to an agrarian society, emptying the cities and forcing their countrymen into agricultural labor.

Source: Time

Khmer Rouge soldiers drive through the capital, Phnom Penh, 1975.

Source: Sjoberg/Afp/Getty Images

Khmer Rouge fighters celebrate as they enter Phnom Penh on April 17, 1975. Prince Sihanouk, the party's early ally, resigned in 1976, paving the way for the now notorious Khmer Rouge founder and leader, Pol Pot, to become prime minister. The country was renamed Kampuchea, and it was the start Year Zero — the beginning of a new history for Cambodia written by Pol Pot.

Source: Claude Juvenal / Afp / Getty Images

Refugees peer through the gate to the French Embassy, begging to get in.

Source: Roland Neveu/Lightrocket Via Getty Images

At the twilight of the Cambodian Civil War, the people of Phnom Penh start to evacuate, as the burning gasoline depot behind them signals the arrival of the Khmer Rouge. 

Source: Claude Juvenal/Afp/Getty Images

Cambodians climb over a fence, trying to escape to the French Embassy. 

Source: Sjoberg/Afp/Getty Images

As the Khmer Rouge moves into the capital, thousands of people abandon their country in fear of what's to come.

Source: Roland Neveu/Lightrocket Via Getty Images

The French Embassy in Phnom Penh struggles to handle the hordes of people begging for protection.

Source: Roland Neveu/Lightrocket Via Getty Images

Days before the occupation of the capital, thousands of Cambodians gather behind a school perimeter fence near the American embassy to watch the final evacuation of U.S. and foreign nationals.

Source: Roland Neveu / Onasia

A crowd gathers around a civilian killed by the Khmer Rouge.

Source: Francoise De Mulder/Roger Viollet/Getty Images

The Killing Fields

Adults were forced to dig their own graves before they were slaughtered with spades and sharpened bamboo. Their children, meanwhile, were smashed to death against the trunks of trees and thrown into the mass graves where their parents lay. There were more than 150 of these killing fields across the country. One of the most brutal, Tuol Sleng, was a former school that transformed into a factory of death. About 20,000 people ended up locked inside of its walls – and only seven got out alive.

Over just four years, from 1975 to 1979, the Khmer Rouge regime exterminated approximately 3 million people. By the end of the genocide, almost 25% of the population had been killed.

A distraught woman cries over the body of her husband, killed by Khmer Rouge soldiers. 

Source: Roland Neveu/Lightrocket Via Getty Images

A terrified prisoner is photographed inside the Tuol Sleng prison. Of the nearly 20,000 people locked in Tuol Sleng, only seven survived.

Source: Wikimedia Commons

Skulls lie in the fields of Choeung Ek.

Source: Roland Neveu/Lightrocket Via Getty Images

Child soldiers working for the Khmer Rouge show off their machine guns.

Source: Bettmann/Getty Images

A soldier stands by a mass grave.

Source: Roland Neveu/LightRocket via Getty Images

A woman rides a bicycle by a stack of destroyed cars, cast aside by the Khmer Rouge as of symbol of the bourgeoisie.

Source: John Bryson/The LIFE Images Collection/Getty Images

Young refugees hide under tall grass, escaping from the killing fields of the Khmer Rouge.

Source: Henri Bureau/Corbis/VCG via Getty Images

A Thai border patrolman finds a dead child that was killed by Khmer Rouge soldiers.

Source: Bettmann/Getty Images

Healing

“No peace without justice”. Unfortunately, despite leading some of the most horrific killings and one of the worst mass killings of the 20th century, only 3 Khmer Rouge leaders were ever sentenced. In August 2014, Nuon Chea - considered Brother Number 2 to Pol Pot - and the regime's head of state Khieu Samphan were jailed for life for crimes against humanity. These were the only convictions for genocide after the whole ordeal. Pol Pot, leader of the Khmer Rouge party was sentenced to house arrest in 1997 and died a year later, denying millions of those who suffered under his regime the chance to gain any justice.

All that was held in 1997 was a show trial in which former comrades of Pol Pot denounced him. Many of the other higher echelon leaders retreated into the countryside after the Vietnamese invasion and were unfortunately, gradually forgotten.

Khmer Rouge guerrillas in the jungle of western Cambodia as they attempt to halt advancing Vietnamese forces on Feb. 15, 1981.

Source: ALEX BOWIE / GETTY IMAGES

Without backing from the Soviet Union, Vietnam could no longer afford to keep its troops in a state of indefinite occupation in Cambodia. In September 1989, Vietnamese troops withdrew from Phnom Penh.

Source: JACQUES LANGEVIN / CORBIS SYGMA

A family greets each other in August 1989 after being separated during years of war and occupation.

Source: MICHAEL FREEMAN / CORBIS

The 1991 Paris Peace Accord that followed Vietnam's withdrawal mandated democratic elections and a ceasefire, but was not fully respected by Khmer Rouge guerrillas. U.N. transitional authority shared power with representatives of various factions, and Prince Sihanouk, shown here at center making his way back the Royal Palace in November 1991, was reinstated as Head of State.

Source: JACQUES LANGEVIN / CORBIS SYGMA

U.N.-run elections in May 1993 resulted in a shaky coalition between Sihanouk's son, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, and Hun Sen, a former Khmer Rouge guerrilla pictured here at a political rally before the elections. The country was once again named the Kingdom of Cambodia. Hun Sen remains Prime Minister today.

Source: ROMEO CACAD / AFP / GETTY IMAGES

Finally agreeing to abandon their fight, the remaining Khmer Rouge soldiers fighters surrendered on Feb. 9, 1999, and donned new uniforms of the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces during an integration ceremony in Anlong Veng near the Thai-Cambodian border.

Source: OU NEAKIRY / AP

Contact sheets showing pictures of what is believed to be former prisoners of the S-21 prison, also known as Tuol Sleng, where over 15,000 people lost their lives. Kaing Guek Eav, better known as Duch, was detained for his role as chief of the torture center in 1999.

Source: DAVID HOGSHOLT / GETTY IMAGES

A long delayed U.N.-backed tribunal to bring the leaders of the genocide to justice began in 2009. On Feb. 17, Duch's trial began. He is the first of five defendants scheduled for trial.

Source: JOHN VINK / MAGNUM PHOTOS

HIST 2791 International Humanitarianism

This website is for our team's final project, to document the genocide in Cambodia from 1975 to 1979 and its effects.
